So let's talk about open source.
What is open source?
There are 10 criteria that define open source.
The main idea is that open source software
is freely distributed along with the source code,
and it doesn't limit the users.
There is no discrimination against people
and against users.
Everyone can use open source software.
We also have cases of software that has public available code,
but it is in open source.
Some examples include the delayed open source license
that a units of another have, maybe MongoDB
server-side public license.

that, because it's really hard for open source
projects to fight against big companies.
The reason for the server-side public license
is that AWS was taking all of MongoDB, selling it as a service,

and they had to maintain and fix the issues.
So why open source?
There are some strong benefits building open source.
You can have a strong community involvement.
You can have transparency, reliability, security.
And it also makes attracting talent easier,
and it avoids also event or looking.
So like community involvement.
There are people around.
Like someone needs a feature.
We might be overwhelmed.

The code is really transparent.
You don't have to trust what the developer claims

And open source software tends to be more reliable and secure.

We have software we always use that is really robust.

So the biggest problem with open source is funding.
Because it's hard to monetize open source software.
We had some major incidents.

hardbleed.

So let's talk about local first software.
In local first software, you control your data.
Everything happens on a machine you control.
There are three major principles.
So the network is optional.
Local data is the primary data.

So by network is optional.
